title: 111_hr4897
content: The Act may be cited as the "Drivers Accelerated Interest Deductibility Act of 2010" or the "Drivers AID Act". Congress acknowledges the importance of a strong automotive industry for the economic health of the United States, with automotive sales historically contributing significantly to retail spending and providing financial security for many Americans. The seasonally adjusted annual rate of automotive sales fluctuated between 17,500,000 units and 14,200,000 units from June 2006 to May 2008. The seasonally adjusted annual rate of automotive sales dropped from 17,500,000 units in June 2006 to 14,200,000 units in May 2008, remaining above the robust industry threshold of 13,000,000 units. However, since June 2008, the rate has averaged less than 10,000,000 units, exceeding 13,000,000 units only three times. In 2008, the automotive new vehicle dealers industry in the United States had substantial contributions to the national economy. The average sales revenue for around 20,000 new automobile dealers was $28.8 million, with total sales reaching $576 billion, accounting for 14.6% of total retail sales. Additionally, there were 1,057,500 employees in new-vehicle dealerships, with an average of 53 employees per dealership. In 2008, 1,057,500 employees in new-vehicle dealerships in the United States earned an average of $48,963 per year, generating a national payroll of over $52 billion. Section 163(h) of the Internal Revenue Code was amended to include a new subparagraph (G) related to qualified vehicle interest based on the national unemployment rate. The term 'qualified vehicle interest' refers to interest properly chargeable on debt for acquiring a qualified vehicle and allocable to a 36-month period. The amount of interest taken into account for a qualified vehicle shall not exceed $5,000. The term 'qualified vehicle' refers to a motor vehicle with the original use starting with the taxpayer, acquired for use by the taxpayer. Only interest on indebtedness allocable to a 36-month period from the date of incurrence can be considered under this provision. The taxpayer must acquire a qualified vehicle for personal use, not for resale, without receiving payment under a specific act, manufactured as a motor vehicle, and classified as such under title II. The taxpayer must acquire a qualified vehicle for personal use, not for resale, which is treated as a motor vehicle under the Clean Air Act, has a gross vehicle weight rating of 6,000 pounds or less, and is a passenger automobile or light truck. The term 'motor vehicle' refers to any vehicle designed for use on public streets with at least 4 wheels, excluding rail-operated vehicles. Other terms like 'automobile', 'passenger automobile', 'light truck', and 'manufacturer' are defined by regulations set by the Environmental Administrator. Additionally, the average national unemployment rate is calculated as the average of monthly rates for months in a calendar quarter, as reported by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, Department of Labor. The deduction for qualified vehicle interest under section 163(h)(5) is allowed in computing adjusted gross income. These amendments apply to vehicles acquired on or after January 1, 2008.
